title: Demonstratives

lessonContent.text: Demonstratives are words used to point out or 'demonstrate' which noun the speaker is referring to, i.e. 'this' or 'that', 'these' or 'those'.
In Spanish they must agree in number and gender with the noun to which they refer, so the words for 'this' and 'these' are as follows:
este/esta/estos/estas are used to refer to things close to the speaker in either time or space:

words2: I like this book. (i.e. the one that is here, near me/in my hand)
These happy days. (i.e. the days that we are enjoying now)

lessonContent.text: There are two sets of words for 'that' and 'those' in Spanish, depending on the degree of proximity in time or space of the object referred to:
ese/esa/esos/esas are used to refer to things slightly further removed than este/esta, etc., or close to the person being spoken to:

words1: ¿Recuerdas esa semana que pasamos en Mallorca?
words2: Give me that newspaper.(i.e. the one near you)
Do you remember that week we spent in Mallorca? (i.e. the one familiar to both of us)

lessonContent.text: aquel/aquella/aquellos/aquellas refer to things that are far away from both the speaker and the person being spoken to, either in time or space:

words2: I like that house. (i.e. the one over there, not near either of us)
It was very hot that summer. (i.e. a long time ago)

lessonContent.text: The difference between ese and aquel is not always clear-cut, and it is difficult to establish hard and fast rules for every use. Careful observation of how native speakers use these two forms will help you to understand the subtle distinctions.

When these forms are immediately followed by a noun, they are demonstrative adjectives, because they give more information about the noun to which they refer. They can, however, be used on their own, in which case they are demonstrative pronouns, as they are taking the place of the noun. When used as pronouns they take a stress mark to distinguish them from the demonstrative adjective form:

words1: Este libro me gusta mucho, pero aquél no me gusta nada.
Estas casas son bonitas, pero aquéllas son feísimas.
words2: I like this book very much, but I don’t like that one at all.
These houses are pretty, but those are very ugly.

lessonContent.text: In Modern Spanish, however, the stress mark is not essential and is frequently omitted.

bContent: Panamá es un país centroamericano que está entre el océano Atlántico (mar del Caribe) y el océano Pacífico. A sus habitantes se les llama panameños. Tiene fronteras con Costa Rica (al norte) y Colombia (al sur). No es un país muy grande ni en términos de extensión (alrededor de 60.000 km2) ni de población (unos 3 millones de habitantes) pero tiene gran importancia geográfica debido al Canal de Panamá, que une el océano Pacífico con el mar del Caribe; aunque construido por los EEUU entre 1904 y 1914, pertenece totalmente a Panamá desde 1999 Panamá es un país culturalmente muy rico y lleno de contrastes. Geográficamente está dividido en 9 provincias (Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colón, Darién, Herrera, Los Santos, Panamá y Veraguas) y una comarca (San Blas). Su capital es la ciudad de Panamá.
